title: 107_hr874
content:
The Hidden Rate Elimination Act of 2001, also known as the Reduction in Marginal Income Tax Rates for Individuals, amends the 1986 Code to reduce tax rates for married individuals filing jointly and surviving spouses. The tax rates for taxable income are as follows:
- Not over $12,000: 14% of taxable income
- Over $12,000 but not over $45,200: $1,680 plus 15% of the excess over $12,000
- Over $45,200 but not over $109,250: $6,660 plus 27% of the excess over $45,200
- Over $109,250 but not over $166,450: $23,953.50 plus 30% of the excess over $109,250
- Over $166,450 but not over $297,300: $41,113.50 plus 35% of the excess over $166,450
- Over $297,300: $86,911 plus 38% of the excess over $297,300. The taxable income of every head of a household is subject to a tax based on a specific table. Taxable income determines the tax rate for unmarried individuals, with rates ranging from 14% to 38% based on income brackets. The tax increases as income exceeds certain thresholds. Taxable income of unmarried individuals (excluding surviving spouses and heads of households) is subject to a tax based on income brackets, ranging from 14% to 38%. Taxable income determines the tax rate, ranging from 14% to 38% based on income brackets. Married individuals filing separate returns also face similar tax rates. Married individuals filing separate returns face a tax determined by a specific table based on their taxable income. The tax rates for taxable income are as follows:
- Not over $6,000: 14% of taxable income
- Over $6,000 but not over $22,600: $840, plus 15% of the excess over $6,000
- Over $22,600 but not over $54,625: $3,330, plus 27% of the excess over $22,600
- Over $54,625 but not over $83,225: $11,976.75, plus 30% of the excess over $54,625
- Over $83,225 but not over $148,650: $20,556.75, plus 35% of the excess over $83,225
- Over $148,650: $43,455.50, plus 38% of the excess over $148,650. The tax rates for taxable income are as follows:
- Not over $6,000: 14% of taxable income
- Over $6,000 but not over $22,600: $840, plus 15% of the excess over $6,000
- Over $22,600 but not over $54,625: $3,330, plus 27% of the excess over $22,600
- Over $54,625 but not over $83,225: $11,976.75, plus 30% of the excess over $54,625
- Over $83,225 but not over $148,650: $20,556.75, plus 35% of the excess over $83,225
- Over $148,650: $43,455.50, plus 38% of the excess over $148,650.
Phasein of Rate Reductions: Tax rates imposed in taxable years beginning in 2002 will be reduced gradually in subsequent years. The tax rates for taxable income will be gradually reduced in taxable years beginning in 2002 and onwards. The Secretary will adjust the tables to carry out the reductions as per the specified schedule. Inflation adjustments will apply in determining rates for 2002 and onwards. The Secretary will not adjust dollar amounts for rate brackets for taxable years after 2001 but before 2007. For years after 2006, adjustments will be made using a cost-of-living adjustment based on 2005. Several provisions are amended to replace "1992" with "2000" in various sections. The following sections are referenced: Section 32(j)(1)(B), Section 41(e)(5)(C), Section 42(h)(3)(H)(i)(II), Section 59(j)(2)(B), Section 63(c)(4)(B), Section 68(b)(2)(B), Section 132(f)(6)(A)(ii), Section 135(b)(2)(B)(ii), Section 146(d)(2)(B), Section 151(d)(4), Section 220(g)(2), Section 221(g)(1)(B), Section 512(d)(2)(B), Section 513(h)(2)(C)(ii), Section 685(c)(3)(B), Section 877(a)(2), Section 911(b)(2)(D)(ii)(II), Section 2032A(a)(3)(B), Section 2503(b)(2)(B), Section 2631(c)(2), Section 4001(e)(1)(B), Section 4261(e)(4)(A)(ii), Section 6039F(d), Section 6323(i)(4)(B), Section 6334(g)(1)(B), and Section 6601(j)(3)(B). The curr_chunk contains various sections of the tax code that are being amended, including changes to percentages in different sections such as 1(g)(7)(B)(ii)(II), 1(h), 531, and 541. These changes involve reducing percentages from 28% to 15% and from 39.6% to 33%. The tax code is being amended to reduce percentages in various sections, such as 1(g)(7)(B)(ii)(II), 1(h), 531, and 541. The changes involve lowering rates from 28% to 15% and from 39.6% to 33%. Other sections are also adjusted to new percentages like 5%, 10%, 15%, and 25%. The Secretary of the Treasury may prescribe alternative percentages to align with existing tables in the Internal Revenue Code. The amendments made by this section to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001, with specific withholding provisions taking effect for amounts paid after the same date. The repeal of phaseouts of deduction for personal exemptions and itemized deductions will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. The repeal of the phaseout of personal exemptions involves amending subsection (d) of section 151 by striking paragraph (3) and making technical amendments to section 1(f). This includes adjusting the dollar amount for inflation in taxable years after 1989. The repeal of the overall limitation on itemized deductions includes the removal of Section 68 and various technical amendments to related sections. This involves striking specific clauses and redesignating others in the tax code. The table of sections for part I of subchapter B of chapter 1 is amended by striking the item relating to section 68, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2001.
